chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Hypercalcaemia - unconfirmed cause
chapter.summary: Covers the management of people with hypercalcaemia of unconfirmed or unknown cause.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 18 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with hypercalcaemia without a confirmed cause?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The management of hypercalaemia depends on the presentation and likely underlying cause.

  • If the person has severe hypercalcaemia or severe symptoms:
    • Arrange emergency admission to hospital for further specialist assessment and management such as intravenous fluids and intravenous bisphosphonate therapy (pamidronate or zoledronate).
  • If the person is asymptomatic or has minimal symptoms, with mild or moderate hypercalcaemia and:
    • A new diagnosis of malignancy is suspected, arrange urgent referral (to be seen within 2 weeks) to an appropriate specialist, depending on clinical judgement.
    • Has a known malignancy which is suspected to be the underlying cause, see the Scenario on Hypercalcaemia - known malignancy for more information on management.
    • A diagnosis of primary hyperparathyroidism is suspected on the basis of serum parathyroid hormone (PTH) results, arrange referral to endocrinology for specialist assessment and management, the urgency depending on clinical judgement.
    • A diagnosis of familial hypocalciuric hypercalcaemia is suspected, arrange referral to endocrinology for specialist assessment and management, the urgency depending on clinical judgement.
    • Is taking any drugs that may be causative or contributory, reduce or stop them if appropriate and recheck the serum calcium at least 3 weeks after stopping the drug. If the adjusted serum calcium confirms ongoing hypercalcaemia after stopping the drug, assess for another underlying cause or arrange referral, depending on clinical judgement.
      • If calcium-alkali syndrome is suspected, review any drugs and consider arranging hospital admission for correction of fluid and electrolyte abnormalities.
      • If the person is taking lithium, liaise with their mental health specialist to discuss whether to stop or reduce the lithium, monitor the serum calcium, or arrange referral to an endocrinologist.
    • A diagnosis of sarcoidosis or other granulomatous disease is suspected, refer the person to a respiratory or other specialist, depending on disease manifestation.
    • A diagnosis of tuberculosis is suspected, see the CKS topic on Tuberculosis for more information on management.
    • A diagnosis of acute kidney injury (AKI) is suspected, see the CKS topic on Acute kidney injury for more information on management.
    • Has known end-stage renal disease (chronic kidney disease, CKD stage 4 or 5), liaise with their renal specialist for advice on ongoing management. See the CKS topic on Chronic kidney disease for more information.
    • A new diagnosis of CKD, see the CKS topic on Chronic kidney disease for more information on further assessment and management.
    • A diagnosis of non-parathyroid endocrine disease is suspected, arrange referral to endocrinology for specialist assessment and management, the urgency depending on clinical judgement.
    • Is immobilized with Paget's disease:
      • Encourage mobilization if possible, and monitor the serum calcium concentration. See the Scenario on Follow-up in primary care for more information on follow-up monitoring.
      • If mobilization is not possible, or the serum calcium concentration remains increased, arrange referral to an endocrinologist, rheumatologist, or specialist in bone disease, depending on local referral pathways.
    • An underlying cause is not obvious (for example, because the PTH level is normal), arrange referral to endocrinology for specialist assessment and management, the urgency depending on clinical judgement.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Specialist assessment and management
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Specialist assessment of a person with hypercalcaemia
  • This may include excluding underlying causes of hypercalcaemia by arranging additional tests.
    • Assessment for familial hypocalciuric hypercalaemia includes 24-hour urine collection for calcium and creatinine excretion and possible genetic testing and screening of family members.
    • Genetic testing may also be offered if there is a family history of hypercalcaemia and/or a suspected inherited endocrinopathy associated with primary hyperparathyroidism, such as a multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndrome.
  • This may include assessing for complications of hypercalcaemia by arranging additional tests.
    • Urinary biochemical stone profile to assess risk of renal stones.
    • Renal imaging such as ultrasound, X-ray, or CT to assess for renal stones or nephrocalcinosis (deposition of calcium salts in the renal parenchyma).
    • X-ray imaging may show skeletal features of primary hyperparathyroidism such as resorption of the distal ends of the clavicles, subperiosteal erosions on the radial borders of the middle or distal phalanges, bone cysts, brown tumours, and pepperpot skull.
    • Bone mineral density by dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) to assess for osteoporosis. There is typically greatest reduction in bone density seen at the distal third of the radius, followed by the hip and lumbar spine.
Parathyroid surgery for primary hyperparathyroidism
  • Parathyroidectomy is the only curative treatment for primary hyperparathyroidism, with cure rates of more than 98% reported in specialist centres. Referral to a parathyroid surgeon allows for pre-operative parathyroid localisation (by ultrasound or nuclear imaging) to guide the surgical approach and technique.
    • Clinical indications for parathyroidectomy include a person with primary hyperparathyroidism with:
      • Symptomatic disease.
      • Age under 50 years.
      • Adjusted serum calcium concentration that is 0.25 mmol/L or more above the upper limit of normal. Note: the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) recommends an adjusted serum calcium level of 2.85 mmol/L or above.
      • Estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) less than 60 mL/min/1.73 m2.
      • Renal stones or presence of nephrocalcinosis on renal imaging; increased renal stone risk on 24-hour urine or biochemical urine analysis.
      • Presence of osteoporosis or vertebral or other fragility fracture.
    • Clinical indications for possible conservative management of primary hyperparathyroidism include a person with:
      • Asymptomatic disease.
      • Age 50 years or over.
      • Adjusted serum calcium concentration that is less than 0.25 mmol/L above the upper limit of normal.
      • No end-organ damage (renal stones, fragility fractures, or osteoporosis) or other co-morbidities making them unfit for surgery.
    • After successful parathyroid surgery, bone density improves, and risk of fragility fractures and renal stones are reduced. Serum calcium levels are typically measured 3–6 months after surgery. Post-operative transient hypocalcaemia may develop (usually mild) in 15–30% of people, however is managed with specialist use of calcitriol and supplemental calcium.
Conservative management of primary hyperparathyroidism if parathyroid surgery is not appropriate
  • If parathyroid surgery is not indicated, declined, contraindicated, or has failed, specialist management of hypercalcaemia may include:
    • Cautious correction of vitamin D deficiency if appropriate.
    • Calcium-lowering therapy with calcitonin which can have a rapid calcium-lowering effect by inhibiting bone resorption and renal calcium reabsorption.
    • Calcium-lowering therapy with the calcimimetic drug cinacalcet which may reduce serum calcium concentration. It does not have an effect on bone density or hypercalciuria.
    • Calcium-lowering therapy with the anti-resorptive agent desunomab, which may have a role in the emergency management of severe refractory hypercalaemia and bisphosphonate-refractory hypercalaemia of malignancy.
    • Bisphosphonate therapy to improve bone mineral density.
    • Glucocorticoid therapy for vitamin D-mediated hypercalcaemia, for example caused by some granulomatous diseases or lymphoma.

[Clines, 2011; Marcocci et al, 2013; Michels, 2013; Bilezikian et al, 2014; Eastell et al, 2014; Udelsman et al, 2014; Meng, 2015; Minisola, 2015; Walsh, 2016; Turner, 2017; Bilezikian, 2018; Insogna, 2018; Zagzag, 2018; NICE, 2019]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on management of hypercalaemia are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guidelines Hyperparathyroidism (primary): diagnosis, assessment and initial management [NICE, 2019], Suspected cancer: recognition and referral [NICE, 2017], Acute kidney injury: prevention, detection and management [NICE, 2013], and Chronic kidney disease in adults: assessment and management [NICE, 2015]; the Society for Endocrinology guideline Emergency management of acute hypercalcaemia in adult patients [Walsh, 2016], the international consensus documents Guidelines for the management of asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism: Summary statement from the fourth international workshop [Bilezikian et al, 2014], Medical management of primary hyperparathyroidism: proceedings of the fourth international workshop on the management of asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism [Marcocci et al, 2013], and The surgical management of asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism: proceedings of the fourth international workshop [Udelsman et al, 2014]; an Endocrine Society clinical practice guideline Paget's disease of bone [Singer, 2014], and expert opinion in review articles on hypercalcaemia [Joshi et al, 2009; Meng, 2015; Minisola, 2015; Turner, 2017], on parathyroid disorders [Pallan et al, 2012; Michels, 2013], and on hypercalcaemia of malignancy [Clines, 2011; Zagzag, 2018].

Arranging emergency hospital admission for severe or symptomatic hypercalcaemia
  • The recommendation to arrange emergency admission if the person has severe hypercalcaemia or severe symptoms is based on the fact this can be a life-threatening condition, requiring intravenous hydration and often bisphosphonate therapy (such as pamidronate and zoledronic acid) to urgently correct hypercalcaemia and reduce the risk of complications [Michels, 2013; Meng, 2015; Minisola, 2015; Walsh, 2016; Turner, 2017].
    • Intravenous fluid therapy and correction of hypovolaemia may improve renal perfusion and restore renal function, and help urinary excretion of calcium [Clines, 2011; Zagzag, 2018].
Management of mild or moderate hypercalcaemia with no or minimal symptoms
  • The recommendation to arrange urgent referral if malignancy is suspected is based on the NICE clinical guideline on suspected cancer [NICE, 2017].
  • The recommendations on when to arrange referral to an endocrinologist are based on the NICE clinical guideline on primary hyperparathyroidism [NICE, 2019] and extrapolated from the international consensus documents on management of asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism [Bilezikian et al, 2014; Udelsman et al, 2014] and expert opinion in review articles [Pallan et al, 2012; Michels, 2013].
    • Specialist endocrinology assessment is helpful to confirm a diagnosis of primary hyperparathyroidism, exclude other possible causes of hypercalcaemia that may present similarly (such as familial hypocalciuric hypercalcaemia), and to advise on the need for parathyroid surgery or conservative management [Pallan et al, 2012].
  • The recommendation to recheck serum calcium levels 3 weeks after stopping any potentially causative drug is extrapolated from expert opinion in a review article, which recommends this washout period following stopping thiazide diuretics [Minisola, 2015]. CKS notes that this contrasts with expert opinion in an alternative review article, which recommends repeating bloods 3 months after stopping thiazide diuretics [Pallan et al, 2012].
  • The recommendation to assess for another underlying cause or arrange specialist referral if the adjusted serum calcium level remains high after stopping the drug is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
    • The recommendation to consider hospital admission for people with suspected calcium-alkali syndrome is based on expert opinion from review articles that correction of fluid and electrolyte abnormalities may be needed [Chan et al, 1997; Yoshizawa, 2012].
    • The recommendation to liaise with the person's mental health specialist if they are taking lithium is based on expert opinion from a review article [Jones and Twomey, 2009].
  • The recommendation to arrange specialist referral if a granulomatous disease is suspected is extrapolated from expert opinion in review articles on sarcoidosis [Wu and Schiff, 2004; Dempsey et al, 2009].
  • The recommendation on the management of people with suspected acute kidney injury (AKI) is based on the NICE clinical guideline on AKI [NICE, 2013].
  • The recommendations on the management of people with end-stage renal disease or suspected chronic kidney disease (CKD) are based on the NICE clinical guideline on chronic kidney disease [NICE, 2015].
  • The recommendations on the management of suspected non-parathyroid endocrine disease is pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
  • The recommendations on the management of immobilization in Paget's disease are largely pragmatic, based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
    • The recommendation to arrange referral if management in primary care is not possible or successful is based on the fact that hypercalcaemia in Paget's disease may be due to co-existing primary hyperparathyroidism, which should be diagnosed and initially managed by a specialist [Singer, 2014].
  • The recommendation to arrange endocrinology referral if an underlying cause is not clear is based on the need for further specialist tests to identify an underlying cause where possible [Joshi et al, 2009].
